14
15#ifndef ISC_LFSR_H
16#define ISC_LFSR_H 1
17
18/*! \file isc/lfsr.h */
19
20#include <inttypes.h>
21
22#include <isc/lang.h>
23#include <isc/types.h>
24
25typedef struct isc_lfsr isc_lfsr_t;
26
27/*%
28 * This function is called when reseeding is needed. It is allowed to
29 * modify any state in the LFSR in any way it sees fit OTHER THAN "bits".
30 *
31 * It MUST set "count" to a new value or the lfsr will never reseed again.
32 *
33 * Also, a reseed will never occur in the middle of an extraction. This
34 * is purely an optimization, and is probably what one would want.
35 */
36typedef void (*isc_lfsrreseed_t)(isc_lfsr_t *, void *);
37
38/*%
39 * The members of this structure can be used by the application, but care
40 * needs to be taken to not change state once the lfsr is in operation.
41 */
42struct isc_lfsr {
43 uint32_t state; /*%< previous state */
44 unsigned int bits; /*%< length */
45 uint32_t tap; /*%< bit taps */
46 unsigned int count; /*%< reseed count (in BITS!) */
47 isc_lfsrreseed_t reseed; /*%< reseed function */
48 void *arg; /*%< reseed function argument */
49};
50
51ISC_LANG_BEGINDECLS
52
53
54void
55isc_lfsr_init(isc_lfsr_t *lfsr, uint32_t state, unsigned int bits,
56 uint32_t tap, unsigned int count,
57 isc_lfsrreseed_t reseed, void *arg);
58/*%<
59 * Initialize an LFSR.
60 *
61 * Note:
62 *
63 *\li Putting untrusted values into this function will cause the LFSR to
64 * generate (perhaps) non-maximal length sequences.
65 *
66 * Requires:
67 *
68 *\li lfsr != NULL
69 *
70 *\li 8 <= bits <= 32
71 *
72 *\li tap != 0
73 */
74
75void
76isc_lfsr_generate(isc_lfsr_t *lfsr, void *data, unsigned int count);
77/*%<
78 * Returns "count" bytes of data from the LFSR.
79 *
80 * Requires:
81 *
82 *\li lfsr be valid.
83 *
84 *\li data != NULL.
85 *
86 *\li count > 0.
87 */
88
89void
90isc_lfsr_skip(isc_lfsr_t *lfsr, unsigned int skip);
91/*%<
92 * Skip "skip" states.
93 *
94 * Requires:
95 *
96 *\li lfsr be valid.
97 */
98
99uint32_t
100isc_lfsr_generate32(isc_lfsr_t *lfsr1, isc_lfsr_t *lfsr2);
101/*%<
102 * Given two LFSRs, use the current state from each to skip entries in the
103 * other. The next states are then xor'd together and returned.
104 *
105 * WARNING:
106 *
107 *\li This function is used only for very, very low security data, such
108 * as DNS message IDs where it is desired to have an unpredictable
109 * stream of bytes that are harder to predict than a simple flooding
110 * attack.
111 *
112 * Notes:
113 *
114 *\li Since the current state from each of the LFSRs is used to skip
115 * state in the other, it is important that no state be leaked
116 * from either LFSR.
117 *
118 * Requires:
119 *
120 *\li lfsr1 and lfsr2 be valid.
121 *
122 *\li 1 <= skipbits <= 31
123 */
124
125ISC_LANG_ENDDECLS
126
127#endif /* ISC_LFSR_H */
128
